summary: The U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York today entered a final judgment against the Commissioner of Social Security's (Commissioner) Objections to the Commission's Decision to Deny Disability Insurance Benefits and Supplemental Security Income (SSI) Benefits to Allaire.  The Commission's Objections, filed on May 25, 2018, alleged that the Commissioner failed to adequately develop the record of Allaire's applications for disability insurance benefits and SSI supplemental security income.  According to the SEC's complaint, the Commissioner's opinion was inconsistent with the record as a whole, including his own treatment notes.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the Commission failed to properly evaluate the record in evaluating Allaire, and failed to consider the evidence presented by the Commission.  As a result, Allaire was unable to perform her duties as a member of the Commission and was not able to participate in any meaningful work activity.  Without admitting or denying the Commission’s findings, the Commission agreed to a judgment that permanently enjoins the Commissioner from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders the Commission to pay a civil penalty in the amount of $1,000,000. The Commission also agreed to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest of $2,038, and to pay civil penalties of $100,000 and $50,000 in the amounts of $20,000 each.  On August 6, 2019, the SEC filed a Complaint against the Commission, seeking a permanent injunction against future violations of Section 5 of the Exchange Act, and a conduct-based injunction prohibiting the Commission from issuing or selling any security in the securities of any broker, dealer, municipal securities dealer, or nationally recognized statistical rating organization. The complaint also seeks a temporary restraining order, an injunction, an officer-and-director bar, and an officer and director bar.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-01-17 (January 2, 2019).  The SEC's Office of Inspector General has issued anÂ Investigative AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool onÂ Securities.gov.Â The SEC's Complaint also alleges that Judge Mahoney erred in determining that, contrary to his findings, a district court should not discount a defendant's opinions and support those reasons with evidence from the record.
